repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Municipal Development, and Urban
            Infrastructure Services Development Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report concurs with the
            Implementation Completion (ICR) ratings on the Urban
            Infrastructure Services Development (UISDP) Project on a
            satisfactory project outcome, likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts. Similarly,
            regarding ratings on the Municipal Development Project
            (MDP), it concurs on a satisfactory project outcome, and
            likely sustainability, and, upgrades the institutional
            development impact from modest to high. Experience with
            these projects highlight the following lessons: 1) Policy
            and programs should continue to focus upon urban services
            improvements, which local authorities and entities should be
            willing to implement and finance, if strengthened local
            credit markets are to be effectively established to work. 2)
            The market for local sub-sovereign credit may be shallower
            than commonly believed. 3) To be profitable and still
            affordable to the poor, local urban services must operate
            very efficiently in order to keep costs down.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Urban Infrastructure Services
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The urban Infrastructure Services
            Development Project for Colombia had the following ratings:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely,
            the institutional development impact was substantial, and
            the Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            The lessons learned indicate that Financiera de Desarrollo
            Territorial (FINDETER) continues to be a development bank of
            fundamental importance in developing the municipal and urban
            services market. At the time the project was formulated
            (1996-97), municipal finance in Colombia was expanding
            rapidly, and longer terms with funding from local financial
            markets seemed imminent. Although private participation was
            mainly concentrated in 2 or 3 sectors in this project, its
            role has proved important in accomplishing the main outcomes
            of the project, and crucial in increasing loan volume in
            response to the crisis. FINDETER has played an important
            role in traditional sectors as water and sanitation,
            education and transport. Although automatic rediscounting
            has proved to be an excellent lending instrument, FINDETER
            should improve this mechanism, partly by learning from other
            second-floor banks' automatic rediscounting. The
            project has demonstrated the need for flexibility, financial
            innovation and continuous learning under the complex
            framework of the economy. Close Bank involvement as part of
            the FINDETER team clearly made important contributions to
            the organization and the operation during the eventful
            period of the project (1997 to mid 2004).

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Urban Infrastructure Services
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Urban
            Infrastructure Services Development Project (UISDP) is to
            contribute to the expansion and solidification of the credit
            market for public autonomous and private providers of local
            public services by enhancing FINDETER's (Financiera de
            Desarrollo Territorial) (Local Development Bank) capacity to
            offer long-term financing for urban infrastructure
            investments. The project's single component will
            consist of urban infrastructure investments consisting of
            subprojects undertaken by public autonomous and private
            entities to develop, improve or expand provision of urban
            public services in eligible sectors (including detailed
            engineering design and construction supervision cost to be
            financed by counterpart funds from project entities).

Colombia - Urban Infrastructure Services
            Development Project

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Second Municipal Development
            Project - social and environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Second Municipal Development Project for Colombia, a
            project to build the institutional capacity of FINDETER, an
            agency which rediscounts loans and offers technical
            assistance; finances investments in urban infrastructure;
            and builds the capacity of municipalities to provide public
            services. The following impacts and mitigations are
            described. Municipal waste management systems or sanitary
            landfills will dispose of solid waste, mainly debris, and
            domestic waste. Hazardous waste will be stored, reused, or
            recycled. Sediments will be prevented from contaminating
            water bodies. Liquid wastes will be diverted to septic
            tanks, lagoons, infiltration fields, or municipal wastewater
            systems.  Rainwater or running water will be stored or used
            in irrigation or for animals. Covering transport vehicles,
            using storage facilities, restricting vehicle operation,
            prohibiting flammable and scrap materials (litter), and
            periodically cleaning public sites bordering the works will
            reduce air emissions. Establishing greenbelt zones,
            reforestation, and replacing vegetal cover will reduce
            erosion as will restoring removed topsoil, to be used to
            spur vegetative growth. Important plants will be extracted
            and stored for later replanting. Drains or barriers will be
            erected to mitigate erosion.

Colombia - Second Municipal Development
            Project - social and environmental impact assessment
